title: Slayer webchat â as it happened | Music | The Guardian
summary: 'the last gig we went to ? madonna in berlin '
'it seems like almost the world is following slayer songs we sing about it , it happens '
'i knew right away , when i had to find somebody to take jeff 's place '
'i 'd love to do a full on real hard rock record one day , super dirty rock'n'roll type of thing '

documents.title: that 's all for today !
text: guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 7:04pm k : cheers , thanks for hanging out .
we 're getting ready to warm up for the brixton show - if we do n't see you tonight , we 'll see you next time.g : ditto !
bishop basher asks , i have heard of the name , slayer , but not knowingly heard anything by you .
what would you suggest as a good introduction for a novice to your music ?
guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 7:03pm k : reign in blood.g : i would say hell awaits .
i like it better than reign in blood .
i love both - but hell awaits , it 's my favourite song to play live .
id8626570 asks , what journey song would you cover if you were asked to play on a journey tribute album ?
guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 7:01pm g : fuckin separate ways !
the guitar riff - neil is one of my favourite guitar players on earth .
all you metalheads - they 're one of the heaviest bands on the planet .
the bay area hated journey , we felt foresaken when they went pop , but they shredded and jammed , synth solos for five minutes like how it should be .
we felt betrayed when they went pop , but i 've grown to like it all .
if i was going to cover an older song , i would do hustler or one of those badass songs .
reddread asks , how did public enemy end up sampling angel of death for she watch channel zero ' ?
was it simply because you were both on the same label at the time , or is there a more interesting story ?
guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:59pm k : there is n't an interesting story - we were asked , were we cool with it .
and we were like : yeah !
ulver asks , kerry king often cites judas priest 's glen tipton as one of metal 's most underrated guitar players .
what did he think of redeemer of souls and the addition of new guitarist ritchie faulkner ?
do you think gary holt contributing to a new slayer album could help slayer put out their best album in over 2 decades ?
( as faulkner helped judas priest to do ) guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:58pm k : i only heard half their new album , and that was on tour somewhere - it was on youtube .

i remembered a couple of the songs stuck out.g : richie shreds - he 's badass.k : when we have days off and we 're in a country where television is not awesome , i had rock'n'roll party night in my hotel room , looking up priest and sabbath videos .
i saw priest 's tour online.g : i saw them doing a warm up show in san francisco - one of the best warm up shows i 've ever seen.k : there is no shortage of priest love here .
before gary starting playing with us , i called him the tipton of our generation .

documents.title: 'the last gig we went to ? madonna in berlin '
text: slayer have another answer to ulver 's question : guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:53pm k : the last show we went to , me and holt , was madonna in berlin .
their guitarist is a big metalhead .
g : he was hired by a guy called guy richie , and hired him to teach madonna to play guitar , and now he plays in her band.k : i went because i knew : when would i go again ?
i knew it was going to be a spectacle of crazy shit , and it was rad - the show was amazing.g : it was my fourth madonna show - i 've been a fan since the beginning .
i 'm a thrash guitarist , but i listen to anything .
there was a time you could n't do that - you could n't listen to anything but metal , it was so close minded .
but i grew up around funk - prince is my hero , the mozart of our generation , a genius .
i was listening to parliament funkadelic at school .
ulver asks , what are the last 3 metal records king & holt bought ?
guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:50pm k : bought ?
that 's the tough part.g : i 'm given a lot of music , so i do n't have to buy a lot the last one i bought , i bought the new hell yeah .
the last cd i bought was marduk , world funeral .
i get so many free albums , nuclear blast has all the great metal bands signed i have all the metal .
i 'm more likely to throw on some old ufo than anything nowadays.k : i 'm in the same boat .
our business , we know all the people who put out record .
i get all my cds from metal blade and nuclear blast - they just load you up .
bought ?
jesus ! g : the most obscure black metal , i did n't have to buy .
gloomy grim , i have their demo cassette that they gave to me , that 's super rare .
or someone burns something for me and hands it to me , like i 've got to check it out .
ian salsbury asks , how frustrating is the negativity from your own fanbase online sometimes ?
are you able to just ignore it/shut it out , or does it become wearing ?
it often seems that a vocal minority have been willing you to fail recently ( judging from the crowd reaction to the brilliant show in plymouth at the weekend , it definitely is a minority though ) .
guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:47pm k : there is that element , of course .
putting this record out , i expected bad stuff : `` it 's only half of slayer , blah blah blah . ''
but you 've still got a songwriter , you 've still got the voice , and it sounds like slayer , no two ways about it .
i do n't dwell on the negativity - you 've got to have thick fucking skin to do what we do , because there 's someone behind a computer somewhere who thinks they 're the coolest shit in years .
but it 's uninformed nonsense , usually .
westmorlandia asks , do you ever wear chinos ?
you know when you 're visiting your parents or something , just to smarten up a touch .
guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:46pm k : what 's a chino ?
that 's my answer.g : like slacks ?
yeah !
i own some very nice clothing .
if it 's a wedding , i show up wearing something for a wedding .
i can be very dapper.k : i do n't need to be dapper .
g : you were in the bloodline video , until they dumped blood all over you .
countcrow asks , i f you could strike out afresh in a new direction musically , right now , what kind of thing would you as a band be interested in ?
guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:44pm g : me i 'd do a gutter rock , rock'n'roll band .
i 'd do some raunchy rock band.k : i have no desire , but if someone said metal does n't exist any more , i 'd have to something so then i 'd play ac/dc .
adelaidewade asks , which non-metal bands would you like to hear covering your songs ?
guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:43pm g : terrence trent d'arby .
everything but the girl .
the prodigy would be good.k : that thought never crossed my mind i do n't think about stuff like that .
that stuff is in gary 's head all the time.g : i 'm a musical encyclopaedia .
i was playing celine dion 's my heart will go on yesterday on guitar and kerry said he was thankful he had never heard that song .
what , you 've never seen titanic ? k : i 'm in a metal bubble - that 's what i like .
if you looked at my ipod , you would expect 96 % of it .
the other four is standup comedy and south park songs .
stonedwolf asks , with legendary guitarist hanneman now deceased and lombardo , who created the slayer drum sound , finally sacked is n't it time you created a different band ?
it 's like the beatles going on tour with paul , ringo and two session musicians .

guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:40pm k : there 's so many ways to argue that and my first answer would be : how stupid would we have looked if we said ac/dc should have ended after bon scott ?
and that you ca n't go on.g : that 's exactly what i was going to say .

documents.title: 'it seems like almost the world is following slayer songs we sing about it , it happens '
text: dan mirza asks , i 'm generalising here but for your first few albums the lyrics mainly concerned satan , hell , and the nazi undead , while for the latest few albums they seem to be more about what a pissed off dude thinks about the world and the people in it , and how he likes to hit people .
you used to invoke a feeling of man 's helplessness in the face of a huge , all-powerful evil , but now the general gist seems to be i 'm going to crush you , rah ! .
kind of comparable to black sabbath 's differences between their satan is going to get us all themes and their rockstar cocaine living stuff .
this brings about a change of vibe , not only when listening to ( and enjoying ! )

your music , but also at your gigs the other night in manchester i thought it was pretty noticeable how the crowd changed from general chaotic moshing for the older tunes ( chemical warfare , die by the sword ) to attempts at organised ' circle-pits for the newer stuff ( and by newer ' i of course mean anything from this century ) .
do n't get me wrong i 've loved you for decades , and you still keep me excited but it feels like there are two different bands here .
not really sure what i 'm asking so i want to hear more please .
thanks gents .
guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:39pm k : i think in the beginning , show no mercy came out when i was 19 and could n't write a song .
i emulated my heroes , and for me that was horror movies .
as you mature as a person and as a songwriter , number one the things you admire change .
i still love horror movies , and writing demonic , satanic lyrics , but we 're done that hardcore for 30 years .
you see more to of interest , you see more of the world and how fucked up it is , especially over here on mainland europe these days .
your perspective on what you want to point out might be different from fictitious , hellish lyrics .
but i 'm still up for doing both .
we just played paris a week before the bombings , we played belgium a handful of days before it closed - and that 's fucked up , people should n't have to live in fear of bullshit .
it seems like almost the world is following slayer songs - we sing about it , it happens .
baddhamster asks , personally , i think dave lombardo is up there with the drumming greats ( bonham , ginger baker , etc . ) .
i know he 's not in the band any more , but would you agree with that appraisal of his skills ?
guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:35pm k : dave is one of the best drummers on the planet , for sure .
i 've got nothing bad to say about his playing.g : he always was more than a metal drummer - he 's a musician , and that 's the ultimate compliment you can give someone .
when they 're more that just what they 're identified from doing .
dino city asks , from a musical perspective , do you worry about slayer becoming less relevant when put alongside more contemporary metal bands ?
guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:34pm k : that 's a pretty vague question !
i 'm not concerned with our relevance - we 're 30 years into these records , and people still ca n't wait to hear these songs .
that 's going to be the same for 40 , 50 , 60 years .
30 years deep is a long fucking time .
john allen asks , would you ever consider doing the next james bond movie theme if approached to do so ?
guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:32pm g : fuck yeah ! k : i did n't like the newest one .
i thought the theme was very meh .
g : live and let die is the best , come on .
skyfall by adele was pretty killer too .
but live and let die , come on.k : live and let die for sure .
i liked it before guns'n'roses redid it.g : oh yeah - it 's heavy .
jordan wolf asks , gary , what is it like working with two bands that have a brutally demanding style of music such as exodus and slayer ?
guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:31pm g : as far as the physical demands , it 's rough .
i have my own physical problems , but i motor through them , and spend my off time getting physically ready for the next show - letting my body heal and rest .
i do n't ever want to be the guy giving 50 % of what he used to - i 'm going to beat my body to a pulp .
i slow down off stage , so i do n't have to on stage .
simaodocaminhao asks , why is it you guys do n't play not a single song from the most aggressive yet most underrated slayer album to date , divine intervention ?
there are so many killer songs on it and they sounded great on live intrusion .
killing fields , sex.murder art or dittohead would with no doubt boost you song live set .

guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:29pm g : we did dittohead for a while , but we have n't done it with paul back in the band.k : every time you do a new record it 's harder and harder - you want to support the new material , and there are old songs you have to play .
g : i 've never done killing fields from that album .
that song is badass.k : that was me trying to outdo rhythm .
it 's good to headbang to , it 's got that little beat.g : a little off-time headbang .
hashim almadani asks , do slayer members know that they have a big fan base in the middle east ?

slayer music had a big influence in our lives : middle eastern metalheads guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:28pm g : when i was on instagram , i had a lot of middle eastern followers .
it 's definitely there .

it 's awesome - some people have to keep that shit hidden depending on what country you 're residing in.k : we finally got to go to india for the first time three years ago , it was really cool because i knew there had been a lot of people wanting us .
it was just one show , and it 's hard to get the tour to multiple territories - if we get the chance to go back , we might do two or three.g : there 's always dubai we can go to the ferrari museum .
christine tomaro asks , i always enjoyed your cover of in-a-gadda-da-vida and i was wondering , can you slayerize any song ?
guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:26pm k : i would imagine , if given enough time , but i do n't like wasting time on that !
that one took a minute , and born to be wild did too .
but the ones on the punk album , that was more natural , because that 's where we came from .
i 'd rather spend time working on new material ; in a gadda da vida and born to be wild , we would never have done them if rick rubin had n't suggested them .
sometimes i wish we had n't done them !
but people like them , so i 'm glad we did .

documents.title: 'i knew right away , when i had to find somebody to take jeff 's place '
text: kaspar berry rapkin asks , with multiple changes of band members , how do you guys ( tom and kerry i guess ) know who 's the right guy ?
is there a test or is it gut instinct ?
or anything else ?
guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:24pm k : i knew right away , when i had to find somebody to take jeff 's place .
the first call i made was gary , and luckily he said yes.g : i thought it would be a couple of months !
it ran a little longer than i originally though , because we thought jeff would get better .
tragically , we all know how it ended .
anas falcon asks , will you and tom collaborate on some songs together like the way tom and jeff did in the past ?
would you also allow tom to write his own slayer songs for the next record ?
guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:23pm k : i do n't think tom has ever tried to write slayer music .
he 's more than welcome , but i do n't see him as a writer of slayer music .
we worked together on pride in prejudice on this new record , but all the others i had already done .
ollie cash asks , once the bands from the eighties ( slayer included ) die off , what do you think will happen to the music scene that they represent ?

guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:21pm g : it would be a big blow - there 's band that carried on , but if you eliminate the originators , it could be crippling but you hope the younger bands keep it alive and continue.k : ideally , somebody sticks their neck out and becomes the new metallica .
because at the end of the day they 're a thrash band .
ideally they get replaced by new bands but that often never happens .
there 'll never be another priest , another sabbath .
but hopefully it morphs and becomes something else - we come from priest and sabbath but we do n't sound just like them .

documents.title: 'i 'd love to do a full on real hard rock record one day , super dirty rock'n'roll type of thing '
text: redmetal99 asks , would you ever consider or have you ever considered experimenting with other genres within metal , or will you always be definitively slayer ?
guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:19pm k : 100 % definitely slayer.g : i have .
it 's all about time - i 've been talking with tony with municipal waste about doing a side project , recording it in a week , a hardcore kind of album .
but it 's all about time - i play in two bands , and it 's hard enough making time for that .
i 'd love to do a full on real hard rock record one day , super dirty rock'n'roll type of thing.k : if i write anything it 's going to sound like this , because i have no itch that needs scratching .
tom wilson asks , any chance we will see gary contributing some riffs for the next album ?
guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:17pm k : i do n't even know when the next record is going to be .
i have n't talked to gary or tom about it , but it 's definitely something that could be in the mix.g : i 'm already writing riffs for the next exodus record , so who knows .
vambeefco asks , - how many guitars do you guys own ?
- did you all start growing your beards at the same time ?
guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:14pm g : i do n't know .
a lot .
there 's not a room in my house that is n't cluttered with guitars - i need to cull the herd a bit .
interested buyers can email me at k : same kind of answer - i know more about what are on tour with me .
i do n't get shit tons a year g : i do !
they 've been raining down on me .
i got about 40 or something like that.k : me , maybe 20 or 30 .
we 've got rigs all over the world.g : i up guitars i have no intention of ever playing live .
k : i win .
97 ! g : i started growing on my own , and so had tom then i shaved mine off and tom had too .
there was no pact - we just showed up shaun .
owenduffy asks , do you think playing such aggressive music helps you be a bit more relaxed in other aspects of life ?
i think people have a misconception that metalheads are all angry and socially maladjusted , but in my experience we do n't tend to fit that stereotype .
guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:11pm g : absolutely .
keeps me grounded and mellow .
other than when it 's necessary to be angry and extreme.k : absolutely was the first word that came to my mind too .
when you see us on the bus after the show , we 're laughing our asses off - it makes sense .
if i do n't get exercise , it 's my exercise .
if i 'm pissed off from being in airports all day , it 's my vent.g : yeah , same here .
theshiftyshadow asks , do you prefer building sandcastles or snowmen ?
guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:09pm g : sandcastles .
i fucking hate the cold - freezing to death constantly over here .
sandcastles means california , where it 's nice outside.k : neither .
anathema 4 asks , what 's been your favourite thing in the uk on this tour ?
guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:09pm k : five guys .
aftershow food in leeds we were looking forward to it for a week.g : we were making the 'five ' sign to each other on stage , we were craving it .
it was fucking beautiful.k : everything tasted exactly the same , down to the bun.g : they ran the franchising of that chain perfectly .
anathema 4 asks , are your necks made of rubber ?
some serious headbanging from you both in leeds ?

guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:08pm k : leeds show was good - the third really good one in a row.g : wales was good too.k : i warm up my fingers , neck and back for an hour and a half , to headbang .
i stretch any direction my neck may go .
g : i just have to make sure my hands work - the rest will follow .
tiago laranjo asks , what if slayer had stayed with metal blade back in 86 ?
guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:06pm k : the next record would have been on metal blade .
reign in blood was done , we just moved on probably would have sounded a little different .
blindalley asks , pick one word to describe the feeling of the band firing on all cylinders .
what is the heaviest song ever ?
worst name you have ever heard for a band ?
guardian contributor slayerband 30 november 2015 6:05pm g : deadly.k : awesome .
g : that 's a hard one .
sweet leaf ? k : since i 'm on the spot , i 'll say : hand of doom .
g : we butter the bread with butter .
it 's a tie with i wrestled a bear once .
my youngest is into that screamo shit.k : limp bizkit .

documents.title: slayer are with us now
text: we 're ready to rock !

documents.title: post your questions for slayer
text: few bands can say they define a style of music , but slayer can make a pretty good claim .

by blending the operatic grandeur of classic metal with the breakneck energy of hardcore punk , thrash metal was born , and slayer used its pummelling insanity to make something truly twisted and massively popular .

their 1986 album reign in blood is seen by many as metal 's greatest ever statement , but other records have been nearly as revered , including this year 's repentless , and 2006 's christ illusion which won them two grammy awards .
the band has successfully weathered the death of founding guitarist jeff hannemann in 2013 , as well as numerous controversies around lyrics that have focused on nazism , jihad and satan .

at 6pm on monday 30 november , before they go on stage at london 's brixton academy , kerry king and gary holt of the band will be answering your questions in a live webchat ( tom araya will be resting his voice , for obvious reasons ) .
post them in the comments below , and they 'll answer as many as possible .

bulletin.text: The definitive thrash-metal band joined us during their UK tour to answer your questions in a live webchat. Catch up with Kerry and Gary's answers here, from the highs and lows of being 30 years in the business to the heaviest song ever and (unlikely) Journey tribute albums.
